Award.AwardTitle: Collabortive Research: Mathematical optimization for targeted macro-molecules delivery to the brain

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Mathematical optimization for
targeted macro-molecules delivery to the brain

Andreas A. Linninger
University of Illinois at Chicago
CBET-0730048

The goal of this research is to study a new computational approach to predict the distribution of infused therapeutic macromolecules in the human brain using advanced medical imaging techniques to measure brain geometry and tissue properties. In particular, the impact of tissue inhomogeneity and anisotropic drug distribution in the three-dimensional human brain will be incorporated. Optimal catheter placement for drug targeting will be computed to reduce toxicity and improve the effectiveness of treatments. Genome maps of receptors can be incorporated into the proposed mathematical model for determining the spatial distribution of the drug activity. This research will be carried out by an interdisciplinary research team composed of two biochemical engineers, a neurosurgeon, and an MRI physicist.

Intellectual Merits: The proposed approach of three dimensional transport drug deliveries in the human brain will (i) bring together recent advancements in medical imaging and rigorous mathematical analysis, (ii) create mathematical formulations for the representation of the inhomogeneous and anisotropic properties of the brain, and (iii) account for the effect of infusion catheter placement.

Broader Impacts: This research will integrate existing medical imaging technology with new mathematical modeling and scientific computing methods. The progress of creating computational grids of the human brain and symbolic codes for cerebral transport phenomena will be shared via the world-wide web to attract attention to the subject and create a growing scientific community. A large educational impact is expected because of the PI's commitment to high school math and science education via the NSF site for research experiences for teachers (RET), as well as his outreach to minorities and underrepresented groups through undergraduate research (REU) mentorship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several treatment modalities for neurodegenerative diseases and tumors of the central nervous system involve invasive delivery of macromolecular drugs to the brain. Despite the ample record of experimental studies, accurate drug targeting to the brain remains a challenge. A promising approach to drug delivery to the brain is invasive drug administration. Invasive techniques involve inserting a drug into the cerebral extracellular space via an infusion catheter, thus by-passing the blood brain barrier.

Convection-enhanced delivery (CED) has received attention because larger distribution volumes can be achieved than by diffusion alone. In CED, volumes of drug distribution depend on (i) infusion parameters like pressure, flow rate and drug concentration; (ii) molecular properties such as effective diffusivity and hydraulic conductivity; (iii) catheter design and position.

We developed a novel analytical solution to the diffusion-convection equation for cylindrical geometry for continuous point sources. It can be used, for example, for simulation and analysis of drug infusion in the brain. It is important to have a clear analytical solution to verify different numerical models and develop CED protocols. Using these models we can predict drug volumetric dispersion from different catheter types.

Three-dimensional computational models of cerebrospinal fluid flow in the brain were developed using the commercial solver ADINA. These models improve our understanding of complex brain physics both in normal subjects and in patients with hydrocephalus. The models predict fluid flow and pressure in extracellular spaces of the cranium as a function of basilar arterial blood flow. Also, our models of intracranial dynamics address key deficiencies like bridging the gap between medical imaging and rigorous mathematical analysis. The models also creates novel mathematical formulations for fluid-structure interactions in porous media which accounts for the dilations of cerebral vasculature.

We developed a novel method entitled computer-assisted brain analysis featuring the following innovations: (i) accurate reconstruction of brain geometry and tissue anisotropy, and (ii) prediction of treatment volumes based on transport principles. The rigorous mathematical framework predicts achievable volumes in target regions as a function of brain anatomy and catheter position. The two and three-dimensional brain anatomy is reconstructed accurately using medical images; tissue anisotropy and heterogeneity are quantified with the help of diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). Our method of computer-assisted brain analysis has also been used to determine distribution volumes of therapeutic nanoparticle solutions delivered by CED.

We also developed a novel experimental technique to monitor drug infusion in vitro using digital image processing. This technique takes into account geometry of the spread and camera calibration which have been overlooked by previous researchers. The method is especially useful for validating our mathematical models which brings CED a step closer to being a clinically safe treatment.
